title: Robert Hooke
summary: Robert Hooke FRS (/hʊk/; 18 July 1635 [N.S. 28 July] –  3 March 1703 [N.S. 14 March][3]) was an English polymath active as a scientist and architect, who, using a microscope, was the first to visualize a micro-organism.[4] An impoverished scientific inquirer in young adulthood, he found wealth and esteem by performing over half of the architectural surveys after London's great fire of 1666. Hooke was also a member of the Royal Society and since 1662 was its curator of experiments. Hooke was also Professor of Geometry at Gresham College.
